criticalPoint.description: According to farmers, grain production in this system barely satisfies the family’s annual demand for grain.
Agricultural production depends on energy provided by humans and animals.
There are no soil conservation practices applied to this system. Hence, soils suffer fertility loss and erosion.
The RAS manages different crops to secure the family’s food self-sufficiency.
Government credits and programs are not equitably distributed. They are monopolized by some producers.

criticalPoint.literal: Low levels of participation in decision-making
criticalPoint.description: Attendance to the ejido assemblies is very low. In addition, there is very little interest on the part of producers to strengthen power of this decision-making organ.

Due to the biophysical conditions of agricultural plots and the socioeconomic situation of the farmers, this system presents problems for the integration of new technology that could help increase agricultural productivity.
The RAS depends very little on external inputs for production.
There is no organization that deals with agricultural production in the ejido, and the only institution, the ejido assembly, which could help regulate and manage resources, is severely weakened.
